title: Orcas Use Kelp for Massage in First Marine Mammal Tool Use Discovery
snippets: Orcas have been filmed using kelp as a tool to massage each other

Killer whales have been seen detaching lengths of seaweed and using them to massage each other—the first evidence of tool-making by marine mammals. The whales bite off the end of a kelp stalk, position it between themselves and a partner, and roll the kelp between their bodies for prolonged periods.

Behavior in orca population off coast of US and Canada captured by scientists using drone observation

Killer whales have been observed mutually grooming each other with a type of seaweed, the first known instance of a marine animal using tools in a way that was previously thought to be the
titles: Killer whales 'massage' each other using kelp

Killer whales seen grooming each other with kelp in first for marine tool use
summary: Scientists have observed killer whales off the coast of the US and Canada using kelp as a tool for mutual massage, marking the first evidence of tool use for grooming in marine mammals. The orcas detach kelp stalks and use them to roll between their bodies and those of their partners, a behavior captured through drone observations. This discovery challenges previous assumptions about tool use in marine animals.
constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights a new discovery in marine biology, providing empowering knowledge about orcas' behavior. It increases clarity around animal behavior, challenging previous assumptions about tool use in marine animals. This new understanding could potentially impact future research and conservation efforts.
